isis.stitle: TSI 96-12-25 - Charge Air Cooler Leak Testing

geninfo.para: When a low engine power complaint is encountered and a leak in the charge air cooler is suspected, you must leak test the Charge Air Cooler (CAC).

note.para: Charge air coolers are not designed to be 100% air tight and leak free. The charge air cooler is not defective if it leaks less than 5 psi in 15 seconds, from a start of 30 psi.

geninfo.para: If testing indicates the Charge Air Cooler is leaking beyond the allowable specification, replace the CAC. Do not attempt to repair the CAC, because field repair is difficult and will void the CAC warranty.

important.para: Charge Air Cooler units returned for warranty will be tested 100%. Any units which meet leak rate will be rejected for warranty reimbursement!
To test the CAC, it is not usually necessary to remove it from the chassis, but you will need compressed air and a Charge Air Cooler Test Kit.

partsinfo.para: If your shop does not have a Charge Air Cooler Test Kit ( Figure 1), it is possible to fabricate one, or you may purchase a Test Kit through the Navistar tool program.

svcproc.title: CAC PRESSURE DECAY TEST

step1.para: Remove piping, hump hoses and clamps from the charge air cooler system. The charge air cooler can remain in the chassis for this test. Existing hump hoses and clamps on the Charge Air Cooler itself will be used for this test. Double clamp all hump hose connections and tighten all constant torque hose clamps to 100 in-lbs.

warning.para: To prevent possible injury from test adapters blowing off, secure safety chains on test adapters to any convenient bolt. Always remain out of line with the test adapters while performing the test and when the system is pressurized.

step1.para: Doublecheck all connections to verify that all joints are tight. Close air pressure regulator and drain valve before beginning test.
Begin test by slowly opening air pressure regulator until test pressure reaches 30 psi. When 30 psi test pressure has been reached, close the air pressure regulator.

warning.para: Do not exceed 40 psi air pressure at any time, as excessive pressure can cause adapters to blow off which may result in injury or damage the cooler.

step1.para: Monitor pressure gauge and determine rate of pressure decay with a stopwatch. System pressure should not drop more than 5 psi in 15 seconds.
After testing, open the drain valve to release pressure. If pressure drop exceeds 5 psi in 15 seconds, re-check all connections.

If a leaky connection is found, tighten the connection and repeat the test. If the leak is within the charge air cooler, repeat the test as many times as necessary to verify the reading. Similar pressure decay readings should be obtained on at least three consecutive tests to verify the reading.

para.emph: If pressure decay does not exceed 5 psi in 15 seconds, the charge air cooler is within acceptable performance limits and should not be replaced.

svcproc.para: For more detailed service information, refer to CTS -5087.
